In the quest for alternative and green energy sources to tackle the energy crisis and environmental pollution challenges, hydrogen fuel cells have been receiving notable attention, owing to their high energy conversion efficiency and negligible to zero emissions. However, the high cost and sluggish reaction kinetics of conventional platinum catalysts for fuel cells have hindered the large-scale commercialization of fuel cells. In this work, we have developed a green synthesis approach for functionalizing iron phthalocyanine (FePc) on B-doped graphene, and employed various characterization methods to elucidate the underlying physical and electronic structure leading to the catalytic activity. The composite catalyst exhibits outstanding ORR activity with an onset potential of 1.01 V, which is on par with commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst. The catalyst also displayed a remarkable half-wave potential of 0.9 V and a limiting current density of 4.7 mA/cm2, both of which were higher than that of Pt/C. Such Pt-free composite catalysts offer a promising solution to sustainable fuel cell applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords ORR Non-precious single atom catalyst Green solvent Onset potential Current density Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Throughout human history, fossil fuels have played a pivotal role in meeting the ever-increasing global energy demand, owing to their abundance, accessibility, high energy density, and practicality. Fossil fuels accounted for approximately 82 % of the world’s total primary fuel consumption in 2021, signifying their predominant role in the energy industry on a global scale [1]. However, the utilization of fossil fuels brings forth a host of challenges such as air pollution, degradation of natural habitats and emission of greenhouse gases. In 2021, fossil fuel consumption was responsible for approximately 94 % of the total global carbon dioxide emissions [2]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to transition towards cleaner alternatives to address these multifaceted issues. In the quest for a clean and sustainable energy solution, fuel cells have emerged as an auspicious source of energy, characterized by their notable energy conversion efficiency, negligible emissions, versatility, smooth operational characteristics, and scalability [3]. Since the invention of the first hydrogen fuel cell in 1842 and its subsequent utilization in NASA’s Gemini and Apollo missions, the advancement of fuel cell technology has significantly accelerated, with exponential growth observed in their adoption across commercial and industrial sectors following the Paris Agreement in 2015 [4–6]. Despite extensive global efforts to promote fuel cell commercialization as a pathway towards a greener future, significant obstacles remain, including challenges related to high manufacturing, maintenance and operating costs, as well as concerns regarding durability and reliability [7,8]. In commercial fuel cell technology, the anode and cathode catalyst are primarily platinum, which comprises a significant portion (38–56 %) of the total fuel cell stack cost [9]. Moreover, the cathode’s oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) involves multiple intermediate steps, leading to the requirement of ten times more catalyst than the anode, and the ORR reaction rate is notably slower, being six or more orders of magnitude compared to the anode reaction [10,11]. Hence, a substantial endeavor has been directed towards the advancement of an ORR catalyst that exhibits enhanced cost-efficiency, superior performance, and heightened durability in comparison to conventional platinum-based catalysts. This pursuit stems from the recognition of the need to overcome the limitations posed by traditional platinum catalysts, which are known for their high cost and susceptibility to degradation, thus hindering the widespread implementation of ORR-based technologies. As a result, researchers and institutions have been investing significant resources and efforts in the pursuit of alternative catalyst materials that can address these challenges and pave the way for more sustainable and efficient electrochemical processes. Recent studies have also reported improved Fe–N–C and CoFe–N–C catalysts for ORR and Zn–air batteries, demonstrating strategies such as ligand modulation of Fe–N4 sites, bimetallic dual-site design, and ZIF-derived nanorods to enhance activity and durability [12–14]. Notably, the historical contribution of Jasinski, who first demonstrated the catalytic activity of cobalt MN4 complexes for ORR in 1964, laid the foundation for subsequent studies on metallophthalocyanines and related molecular catalysts [15]. Iron phthalocyanine (FePc) molecular catalyst has garnered significant attention among the documented non-platinum oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts, which is attributed to its distinctive active sites of FeN4 and the comparatively lower activation energy during ORR [16,17]. In this context, Zagal and others have made significant contributions by developing reactivity indexes for ORR using MN4 macrocyclic complexes, providing a theoretical and experimental framework to correlate electronic structure descriptors with catalytic performance [18–20]. Despite the growing interest, a comprehensive understanding of their true catalytic active sites is lacking and remains a subject of intense debate and scrutiny. Xu et al. conducted a thorough examination of ORR catalyzed by thirteen distinct N-liganded Fe-NxC configurations to achieve a deeper understanding of the origin of Fe-N-C electrocatalytic activity [21,22]. Their findings indicate that ORR catalytic activity of pyrrole Fe-NxC surpasses that of pyridine, and the conversion of in situ active centers to ∗O-FeN4C and ∗OH-FeN4C elucidates the origin of the heightened activity of Fe-N-C in alkaline media [22]. Despite possessing potential active sites for absorption of oxygen molecules and accelerating reduction process, the ORR activity of FePc is restricted by inferior electron conductivity and severe aggregation among themselves [23,24]. To enhance the electron transfer properties and prevent aggregation of the active sites, FePc has been immobilized on graphene surface through π-π stacking interaction [25,26]. To further promote the ORR activity of the composite catalyst, heteroatom doping of graphene substrate have been implemented extensively, which modifies the electronic properties of graphene by instigating charge and spin densities on the C atoms adjacent to the dopants [27]. Among various heteroatom-doped carbon materials, N,B-codoped graphene has also been reported to enhance catalytic activity in electrochemical applications, as demonstrated by Zheng et al. [28]. A computational approach by Helsel et al. to optimize FePc supported on graphene substrate reveal that B doping of the graphene substrate reduced the overpotential of the rate determining step by modulating the filling of Fe eg orbitals and boost the ORR activity of the catalyst [29]. Inspired by the potential ORR activity of FePc and B-doped graphene, we planned to conduct a comprehensive experimental research work using FePc to functionalize B-doped graphene and evaluate its ORR electrocatalytic performance in alkaline media using various electroanalytical techniques. 2 Methodology 2.1 Synthesis procedure of iron phthalocyanine (FePc) functionalized boron doped graphene (BG) Iron (II) phthalocyanine (FePc) (96 %) was purchased from Alfa Aesar, while 20 wt% Pt on graphitized carbon (Pt/C) and boron doped graphene (BG) were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich. The BG specifications as stated by the manufacturer: BET surface area ≥ 500 m2/g, 2 % B, average number of layers = 1–5. In a model experimental setup, 7.5 mg of BG and 10 mg of FePc were individually dispersed in ethanol at a concentration of 0.1 mg/ml. The FePc and BG dispersions were sonicated initially by using a QSonica Q700 probe sonicator at 50 Hz for 2 min, after which the sonication was continued in a Cole-Palmer 8890 bath sonicator for 1 hour. The BG dispersion was then taken in a beaker and stirred using a magnetic stirrer, while dropwise addition of FePc dispersion was carried out using a burette. The FePc-BG combined solution was stirred at 700 rpm for 4 h. After stirring, the resultant mixture was stirred again on a magnetic stirrer with hot plate applying a rotation rate of 400 rpm and a temperature of 90 °C under a fume hood. The mixture was allowed to evaporate until a slurry was obtained, which was heated in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 4 h. The resultant powder of the FePc functionalized BG (BGFePc) catalyst was collected and weighed. The composition of BGFePc was varied by applying different weight ratios of FePc:BG, such as 2:1, 1:1, 0.75:1 (1:1.33) and 1:2, for 67 wt% FePc (BGFePc67), 50 wt% FePc (BGFePc50), 43 wt% FePc (BGFePc43) and 33 wt% FePc (BGFePc33). 2.2 Preparation of Iron phthalocyanine (FePc) on carbon support Carbon Black Vulcan XC-72 was acquired from Fuel Cell Earth and a similar synthesis procedure described in the above section was employed to prepare FePc on carbon support. The FePc:C ratio was kept 0.75:1 or 43 wt% and the synthesized catalyst was labeled as CFePc43 for control experiments. 2.3 Physical characterization Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) imaging was done using a Jeol NEOARM 200CF Transmission Electron Microscope. UV–Vis spectroscopy was conducted using a Thermo Scientific Evolution 260 Bio UV–Visible Spectrophotometer, coupled with an Insight 2.1.133 software. The parameters of the UV–Vis measurements were wavelength range from 1000–200 nm, bandwidth of 2 nm, integration time of 0.1 s, data interval of 1 nm and a scan speed of 600nm/min. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer equipped with diamond ATR crystal and combined with an Omnic 9.13.1224 software. The FTIR was run in absorbance mode with the measurements consisting of with 16 scans, a resolution of 4, and a data spacing of 0.482 cm−1. Samples were in powdered form and the blank background scan was taken prior to the measurements. 2.4 Electrochemical characterization 2.4.1 Electrochemical measurements While membrane electrode assembly (MEA) measurements provide the most representative data for evaluating the performance of practical fuel cell systems, it is essential to employ simpler techniques to assess the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance of the catalyst during its initial stages of development on a laboratory scale [30]. Rotating disk electrodes (RDE) are one such popular and efficacious method for evaluating the ORR activity of a catalyst. All electrochemical measurements were performed in a three-electrode system using a Pine Research Wavedriver 200 bi-potentiostat combined with a Wavevortex 10 rotator. The counter electrode was a coiled Pt wire, while the reference electrode was a single junction Ag/AgCl (4 M KCl w/AgCl) electrode (SSCE). The working electrode was a 5 mm glassy carbon electrode (GCE), which was mounted on a rotating disk electrode (RDE) setup. The working electrolyte was 0.1 M KOH, and 200 ml of the electrolyte was used to fill up a PTFE cell. All electrochemical measurements were carried out at a scan rate of 10mV/s in a N2/O2 saturated medium, and the potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) potential unless stated otherwise by using the following equation: E R H E = E S S C E + 0.1976 + 0.0591 × p H . To prepare the working electrode, the GCE was first polished on a nylon polishing pad with 0.3 μm alumina slurry and then polished on a microfiber polishing pad with 0.05 μm alumina slurry, followed by a 1 min sonication on bath sonicator to remove all contaminants. The BGFePc catalyst ink was prepared by mixing specific amount of BGFePc powder with ethanol and 5 % w/w Nafion dispersion, while keeping the Nafion to catalyst ratio (NCR) around 0.4. After mixing, 10–20 μL of the catalyst ink was drop casted on the GCE, and the volume of the catalyst ink was varied according to the preferred catalyst loading. The CFePc43, FePc and BG ink were prepared in a similar manner as the BGFePc ink. To prepare the Pt/C ink, 1 mg of 20 wt% Pt/C powder was mixed with 800 μL of DI water, 190 μL of ethanol and 10 μL of Nafion to form a homogeneous ink. Then, 20 μL of the ink was drop casted on GCE and dried. The Pt/C loading on GCE was 0.1 mg/cm2 (20.4 μg Pt/cm2). The catalyst ink on GCE was dried using three separate techniques such as the stationary drying, stationary drying with N2 and rotational drying at various speeds. Prior to the electrochemical measurements, the electrolyte solution was purged with N2/O2 for at least 30 mins to ensure saturation. Measurements were performed in O₂-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolytes, with N2-saturated solutions used for background correction. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was employed at 10 mV s−1 to probe redox behavior and establish onset/half-wave potentials, while linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) under RDE control provided kinetic and mass-transport parameters. From these, the electron transfer number and kinetic current were determined via Koutecky–Levich analysis, and Tafel slopes were derived to evaluate intrinsic reaction kinetics. Catalyst durability and stability were further examined by chronoamperometry (CA), where current retention was monitored under applied potential. Note that the onset potential was defined as the potential measured at a threshold current density of 0.1 mA/cm2. The polarization curves were recorded at a scan rate of 10 mV s-1 under O₂ at 1600 rpm. Although lower scan rates (1–5 mV s-1) can better approach quasi-steady-state conditions, the use of 10 mV s-1 is common in ORR benchmarking protocols and offers practical advantages, such as minimizing time-dependent drift (including baseline shifts, bubble accumulation, and catalyst ink dehydration) without compromising kinetic parameters. This scan rate choice aligns with established practices in the field [31,32]. 2.4.2 Computational methods Spin-polarized density functional theory simulations were performed using the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP). Projected-augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials with a plane-wave cut-off of 400 eV were used. The interactions between valence electrons and frozen cores were described using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [33,34] form of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [35,36]. Van der Waal interactions were used to describe long-range dispersion corrections; a semi-empirical scheme proposed by Grimme (DFT-D2) was used [37]. Gaussian smearing with a width of 0.05 eV around the Fermi level, with electronic energies converged to 10−6 eV, and <0.02 eV/Å of residual forces for ionic relaxations was used. The Brillouin zone was sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 and 9 × 9 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh for relaxations and DOS simulations, respectively. The dimensions of the cell used for DFT simulations was 17.07 × 14.78Å in the x and y directions, with 25Å in vacuum in the Z direction to ensure negligible interactions between periodic images. The cell consisted of an optimized single layer slab model graphene sheet with 1.42Å CC bond lengths with FePc placed on top and relaxed. More details of the computational methods for relaxations, DOS simulations, overpotential calculations, and dopant placement can be found in our previous publications [38,39]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy As previously mentioned, FePc has an extended 18-π electron conjugated system which can interact with similar delocalized π electron system of BG through π-π stacking interaction [40,41]. Hence, FTIR spectroscopy measurements were conducted to elucidate the interaction between FePc and BG. Initially, we did FTIR spectra of B-doped graphene to confirm the presence of B in the purchased B-doped graphene sample as shown in Fig. S1 in supplementary information. Two dominant peaks can be seen at 1329 cm−1 and 1617 cm−1 in the FTIR spectra. The peak at 1617 cm−1 is clearly resembled with C = C stretching of sp² carbon framework, corresponding to the skeletal vibration of the graphene aromatic domains. The new peak appears around 1329 cm−1 clearly attributed to B–C stretching vibrations. This is a key fingerprint of boron doping. The FTIR spectra of FePc and BGFePc powdered samples can be seen in Fig. 1 . The characteristic peaks of FePc at 721, 754, 1089, 1122, 1166, 1289, 1335, 1422 and 1513cm−1 correspond to the vibrational modes of different bonds present within the FePc macrocycle [42–44]. The bond nature associated with the characteristic peaks of FePc and their vibrational modes are given in Table 1 . Analyzing the BGFePc spectra, it was found that the peaks of BGFePc experience a red shift when compared to that of FePc. This red shift bear evidence of the possible π-π stacking formation between FePc and BG [45–47]. 3.2 UV–Visible (UV–Vis) spectroscopy To gain further insight into the structure of BGFePc catalyst, UV–Vis spectroscopy measurements were carried out using dilute solutions of FePc and BGFePc in cuvettes. The UV–Vis spectra of FePc and BGFePc is illustrated in Fig. 2 . The FePc spectrum exhibits a broad B band between 300–450 nm which is attributed to transitions from a2u and b1u to eg ∗ orbitals, and a strong Q band between 600–750 nm arising from the π-π* transitions from a1u to eg ∗ orbitals [48–50]. The FePc spectrum in Fig. 2 shows a B band at 333 nm, a Q band at 641 nm and a weak satellite band at around 560 nm, which is caused by aggregation between FePc molecules [48]. As for the BGFePc spectrum, it experienced an overall decrease in intensity and the Q band shifted to 658 nm. The decreasing intensity can be attributed to the anchoring of FePc on BG, while the red shift of the Q band results from the effect of ring currents in FePc and BG π-electron systems [51,52]. The bathochromic shift of the Q band bears evidence of the π-π stacking formation between FePc and BG [53,54]. 3.3 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) TEM imaging was conducted to study the surface morphology of BG, FePc, BGFePc43 and BGFePc67. The TEM image of BG is shown in Fig. 3 a, where the surface of BG displays a smooth texture with occasional wrinkles distributed across its surface area. Fig. 3b shows the TEM image of FePc, where the columnar structure of FePc is clearly visible, and the FePc molecules aggregate among themselves to a great extent. After immobilizing FePc on BG surface, the FePc molecules are stabilized, resulting in a significant reduction in the degree of aggregation, as it can be seen from the TEM image of BGFePc43 catalyst in Fig. 3c. The image reveals a uniform distribution of FePc molecules across the BG surface, characterized by a random orientation. Moreover, the observed aggregation of FePc is notably reduced compared to the unsupported FePc. As the weight percentage of FePc is increased from 43 wt% to 67 wt% in the BGFePc67 catalyst, there is a noticeable increase in aggregation, leading to the congestion of FePc aggregates on the surface of BG. In the TEM images, FePc domains appear as submicron aggregates on the graphene substrate. While these domains likely consist of stacked FePc molecules, no distinct lattice fringes were observed to confirm crystallinity; therefore, we conservatively refer to them as FePc aggregates 3.4 Electrocatalytic performance 3.4.1 Commercial 20 wt% PT/C catalyst (Pt/C) To evaluate the ORR performance of the BGFePc catalyst, electrochemical performance tests were carried out for commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst for comparison of relevant parameters. For that, 20 μL of Pt/C ink was drop casted on GCE, dried by stationary drying and mounted on RDE. The catalyst loading was 0.1 mg/cm2 (20.4 μgPt/cm2) and NCR was 0.4. Then, 200 ml of 0.1 M KOH was taken in the PTFE cell and saturated with N2/O2 for at least 30 min. The CV, ORR polarization, RDE-LSV, and K-L plots for 20 wt% Pt/C can be found in Figures S2-S4. The CV curve shows that Pt/C reaches a maximum current density of 0.73mA/cm2 at a cathodic ORR peak of 0.88 V. The results will be compared against in later plots. While Pt/C typically exceeds 5 mA/cm² at 1600 rpm, the lower values here may stem from oxygen transport limitations caused by non-uniform films when using ethanol as the ink solvent. 3.4.2 BGFePc catalysts After Pt/C, BGFePc catalysts with varying compositions were evaluated in similar procedure. Since the distribution of FePc on BG surface was optimum for BGFePc43 with the least amount of aggregation, as per TEM images, BGFePc43 (43 wt% FePc) catalyst was tested initially to evaluate the ORR activity. The catalyst loading and NCR was 0.3 mg/cm2 and 0.4 respectively. After that, the GCE was loaded on RDE and CV, RDE-LSV and K-L analysis was carried out. 0.1 M KOH was saturated with O2 in a similar manner mentioned before. The CV curve of BGFePc43 can be seen in Fig. 4 , which reveals a prominent ORR peak at 0.9 V and a peak current density of 0.78 mA/cm2. The cathodic ORR peak potential and current density of BGFePc43 were both higher than those of Pt/C (0.88 V and 0.73 mA/cm2 respectively). The ORR polarization curve of BGFePc43 in Fig. 5 further establishes the superior ORR activity of the catalyst. From the curve, the onset potential was found to be 1.01 V, which is on par with the onset potential of Pt/C (1.01 V). The half-wave potential of BGFePc43 was determined to be higher than that of Pt/C (0.87 V) with a value of 0.9 V. The polarization curve of BGFePc43 further revealed a kinetic current density and limiting current density of 1.6mA/cm2 and 4.7mA/cm2 respectively, both of which were higher than the corresponding values of Pt/C. The number of electrons transferred in ORR was calculated from the K-L plot in Fig. 6 , and it ranged between 4.15–4.17. The calculated electron transfer number was above 4, which we attribute to experimental artifacts such as limited O2 solubility, film resistance, and non-uniform catalyst distribution caused by ethanol-based ink preparation. These effects reduce the apparent limiting current density relative to the theoretical Levich value and lead to minor deviations in the Koutecky–Levich analysis; thus, the data remain consistent with a four-electron ORR pathway. 3.4.3 BGFePc catalysts with varying wt% of FePc and effect of catalyst loadings BGFePc67 (67 wt% FePc) and BGFePc33 (33 wt% FePc) catalysts with both a higher and lower weight percentage of FePc compared to BGFePc43 were then tested for the evaluation of their electrocatalytic performance. The catalyst loadings on GCE for BGFePc67 and BGFePc33 were 0.1 mg/cm2 and 0.78 mg/cm2 respectively, and the NCR was 0.4. The CV and ORR polarization for BGFePc67 and BGFePc33 can be found in Figures S5-S6. Figure S5 shows that the current density of BGFePc67 peaked at 0.83 V with a value of 0.39 mA/cm2, and the current density for BGFePc33 was found to be 0.59 mA/cm2 at a peak cathode potential of 0.86 V. From Figure S6, the onset potential of BGFePc67 and BGFePc33 were calculated from the ORR polarization curves to be 0.94 V and 0.95 V for BGFePc67 and BGFePc33, respectively. The onset potentials observed for BGFePc67 and BGFePc33 were notably lower than that of BGFePc43. A higher FePc content in BGFePc67 led to the aggregation of FePc molecules within the BG surface and subsequent blocking of active sites, while lower FePc content in BGFePc33 resulted in the scarcity of active sites. This highlights the significance of the 43 wt% FePc composition within the BGFePc composite catalyst, affirming it as the optimal FePc composition that yielded superior results. The effect of different BGFePc43 catalyst loadings on GCE was tested by varying the loading from 0.1 mg/cm2 to 0.4 mg/cm2. The results are shown in Figures S8-S9. Comparing the results, a catalyst loading of 0.3 mg/cm2 was found to have the highest current density (0.78 mA/cm2), while a loading of 0.4 mg/cm2 yielded the highest peak cathode potential (0.93 V). The onset potential of BGFePc at various loadings did not differ from each other, but the limiting current density varied to some extent, with 0.3 mg/cm2 yielding the highest limiting current density among the other loadings. Based on the CV and RDE-LSV test results, BGFePc43 catalyst loading of 0.3 mg/cm2 was determined to be the optimum loading content on GCE. Changes in catalyst loading influenced the current density, yet the onset potential remained consistent, independent of the loading on GCE. It should be noted that we present the polarization data at the actual loadings used, without normalizing by catalyst mass. This choice reflects practical testing conditions, where PGM-free catalysts are commonly applied at higher loadings than Pt/C due to differences in cost and material abundance. Direct normalization could obscure these realistic conditions and lead to misleading comparisons; therefore, the data are shown as measured. 3.4.4 ORR activity of FePc, BG and CFePc43 Similar experiments (CV and RDE-LSV) were carried out using FePc, BG and CFePc43 as catalysts to compare the ORR activity with BGFePc43. The catalyst loading was 0.3 mg/cm2 on GCE and the NCR was 0.4 for all the catalysts discussed above. The CV and ORR polarization for FePc and BG can be found in Figures S10 and S11. The CV, ORR polarization, RDE-LSV, and K-L plots for CFePc43 can be found in Figures S12 and S13. The results are explained in the supplementary and will be compared against in the next section. 3.4.5 Comparison of ORR activity The CV test results of commercial 10 wt% Pt/C (0.1 mg/cm2 loading), BGFePc43 (0.3 mg/cm2 loading), CFePc43 (0.3 mg/cm2 loading), FePc (0.3 mg/cm2 loading) and BG (0.3 mg/cm2 loading) are displayed in Fig. 7 for the comparison of ORR activity. In terms of current density, CFePc43 yielded the highest current density with a value of 0.8 mA/cm2, closely followed by BGFePc43 (0.78 mA/cm2) and BG (0.76 mA/cm2). However, the error bars of the current densities of CFePc43, BGFePc43 and BG overlap to some extent, pointing out the fact that there is little to no difference in the current densities of these catalysts. The peak cathode potential of CFePc43 was also the highest with a value of 0.91 V. Upon analysis and comparison of FePc with the corresponding values of BGFePc43, it was observed that the current density, onset potential, half-wave potential, kinetic current density at 0.9 V and the limiting current density are lower than those of BGFePc43. This observation indicates the fact that ORR activity is enhanced significantly due to the anchoring of FePc on BG surface and the resulting π-π stacking interaction between FePc and BG. To gain further insight into the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts, the RDE-LSV test results of commercial 10 wt% Pt/C (0.1 mg/cm2 loading), BGFePc43 (0.3 mg/cm2 loading), CFePc43 (0.3 mg/cm2 loading), FePc (0.3 mg/cm2 loading) and BG (0.3 mg/cm2 loading) were combined in Fig. 8 . Analysis of Fig. 8 reveals that BGFePc yielded the highest onset potential (1.01 V), which is equal to that of Pt/C. BGFePc also exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.9 V, which is highest among the corresponding values of other catalysts in comparison. Though CFePc43 displayed the highest kinetic current density (1.8 mA/cm2), the corresponding value of BGFePc43 fell short by only 0.02 mA/cm2 with a value of 1.6 mA/cm2. Regardless, the limiting current density of BGFePc43 was greater than the other catalysts, with a value of 4.7 mA/cm2. 3.4.6 Tafel plot analysis The Tafel plot analysis was carried out to investigate the ORR kinetics of the catalysts. Equation 2 was used to determine the Tafel slope, and the Tafel plot is shown in Fig. 9 . Since the range of intermediate overpotentials (100–300 mV) is considered as the Tafel region, the potential range of the Tafel plot was taken from 1.02 V to 0.86 V (210–370 mV overpotential). Analyzing the Tafel slope values, it was found that BGFePc43 had a lower Tafel slope (60.2mV/dec) than both its precursors (FePc and BG) and Pt/C, indicating a higher ORR rate. The active sites of FePc are hindered by the aggregation of FePc molecules, whereas in BGFePc the degree of aggregation was considerably reduced, resulting in higher availability of the active sites for ORR. A slope near 60 mV dec−1 is generally associated with a first electron–proton transfer step that is not rate-limiting, implying that subsequent reduction of OOH plays a key role in controlling the overall kinetics [55,56]. In contrast, slopes closer to 120 mV dec−1 are typically linked to a one-electron transfer to O2 as the rate-determining step. It is suggested that the reduced aggregation of FePc molecules in BGFePc43 therefore enhances the availability of Fe–N4 active sites, leading to improved ORR kinetics consistent with the observed 60.2 mV dec−1 slope. 3.4.7 Chronoamperometry As seen in Fig. 10 , the stability of the catalysts was assessed by chronoamperometry, where the current response was monitored at a constant potential of 0.8 V for 2 hrs (7200 s). The relative current of FePc dropped drastically to 13.8 % due to the poor stability of the aggregated molecules, while BGFePc43 retained about 75.7 % of its initial current after 2 hrs. As for CFePc43, the initial current reduced to 59 %, asserting that carbon support does not sufficiently stabilize FePc on its surface. 3.5 Comparison of ORR parameters The π-π stacking formation of FePc and BG in BGFePc43 not only enhanced the ORR catalytic performance of FePc, but also stabilized the overall composite catalyst structure, presenting it as a potential ORR electrocatalyst for practical fuel cell applications. Once all the electrocatalytic ORR experiments were concluded, the ORR parameter values of the catalysts were compiled and tabulated in Table 2 . In terms of onset potential and half-wave potential, BGFePc43 outperformed all the other catalysts in comparison, with the onset potential value being the same as the commercial 10 wt% Pt/C catalyst. The composite catalyst also yielded the highest limiting current density and a higher kinetic current density than Pt/C. The lower Tafel slope of BGFePc43 compared to Pt/C was indicative of the fact that ORR propagated at a faster rate on BGFePc43 due to its remarkable ORR activity. Comparing the ORR parameter values of BGFePc43 with those of FePc, it was evident that the anchoring of FePc molecules on the surface of BG enhanced the ORR activity of FePc and increased its stability. As for CFePc43, the carbon support aided FePc in achieving decent ORR activity, but did not stabilize the FePc adequately, as it was found from the chronoamperometric response. When evaluating the half-wave and onset potentials of the synthesized BGFePc43 in comparison to the values found in Gewirth et al., it is observed that the onset potential exceeded 83 % of the reported onset potential values [57]. Moreover, the half-wave potential surpassed that of 86 % of the catalysts’ reported values. Despite the simplicity of the synthesis method used for the composite catalyst, BGFePc43 demonstrated impressive ORR activity. The solvent used in the synthesis procedure of BGFePc43 was ethanol, which is ideally not the most favorable solvent for dispersing FePc and BG nanoparticles. Ghani et al. reported the solubility properties of metal phthalocyanines where organic solvents such as dimethylformamide (DMF), tetrahydrofuran (THF) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) were preferred over ethanol as a solvent due to their higher solubility of FePc [48]. As for graphene, organic solvents like N-methyl-2-pyrollidone (NMP), DMSO, DMF and N-cyclohexyl-2-pyrollidone (CHP) have been proven to disperse graphene effectively [58]. However, due to their high boiling point coupled with their toxic and hazardous nature, these solvents were not selected for the synthesis process. TEM images from Fig. 3c showed notable reduction of FePc aggregation in BGFePc43 as compared to the unsupported FePc, but the aggregation was still present. Following a different synthesis procedure or using a different solvent might have resulted in a better distribution and much lowered aggregation of FePc on BG substrate, which in turn could have further enhanced the ORR electrocatalytic performance of BGFePc. The effect of film deposition technique is discussed and shown in Figure S14. 3.6 Computational agreement To further understand the effect that B-doped graphene has on stabilizing and increasing the performance of FePc, the computationally calculated overpotential of 1 %-B-GFePc, 2 %B-GFePc, and GFePc was plotted against their eg band center. The specifics of how these overpotentials were calculated and what other dopants and variations were tested can be seen in our previous publication Helsel et al. [39]. The results shown in Fig. 11 a show that the addition of boron into the graphene matrix moves the band center closer toward the Fermi energy level while also lowering the overpotential required to facilitate ORR. In another one of our previous publications, the stabilities of 1 %-BGFePc and GFePc were computed as a function of potential and pH utilizing the dissolution and intermediate reactions [38]. The results of this study can be seen in Fig. 11b, with the results simplified to compare the overall 1 %-BGFePc and GFePc ranges rather than broken down by intermediate. Though both complexes are relatively stable in the range of potentials and pH’s tested, it was found that the BGFePc and its intermediates were able to withstand a slightly more positive potential range than GFePc. These computational results showing enhanced activity and stability of BGFePc in comparison to GFePc are in good agreement with the experimental results found in this study. 4 Conclusion This research was undertaken to develop a cost-effective catalyst capable of surpassing the performance of commercial Pt/C as an ORR electrocatalyst in alkaline fuel cells. With this objective, we employed a straightforward synthesis approach, functionalizing boron-doped graphene with iron phthalocyanine using ethanol as a non-hazardous solvent. The homogeneous distribution and significantly reduced aggregation of FePc molecules on BGFePc43 composite catalyst was evident from the TEM images. The confirmation of π-π stacking interaction between FePc and BG via FTIR and UV–Vis spectroscopy played a pivotal role in enhancing the ORR catalytic activity of the BGFePc composite. Based on the electrocatalytic ORR performance, the optimal FePc content for the BGFePc catalyst was determined to be 43 wt% FePc, with a loading of 0.3 mg/cm2 demonstrating the highest ORR activity. BGFePc43 catalyst exhibited remarkable ORR activity, showcasing an onset potential equivalent to that of Pt/C while surpassing the half-wave potential and current density of the commercial Pt/C catalyst. This superior ORR performance of BGFePc was further evident from the Tafel plot, where it yielded a lower Tafel slope than Pt/C, indicating a higher reaction rate. Moreover, BGFePc displayed decent stability in chronoamperometric response, retaining 75.7 % of its initial current after 2 h, a significant improvement over its precursors. This superior performance can be attributed to the π-π stacking interaction and the resultant synergistic effect between FePc and BG. The findings of this study offer valuable insights for the future design of metal-N4/graphene composites, paving the way for the next generation of cost-effective alkaline fuel cell catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In the quest for alternative and green energy sources to tackle the energy crisis and environmental pollution challenges, hydrogen fuel cells have been receiving notable attention, owing to their high energy conversion efficiency and negligible to zero emissions. However, the high cost and sluggish reaction kinetics of conventional platinum catalysts for fuel cells have hindered the large-scale commercialization of fuel cells. In this work, we have developed a green synthesis approach for functionalizing iron phthalocyanine (FePc) on B-doped graphene, and employed various characterization methods to elucidate the underlying physical and electronic structure leading to the catalytic activity. The composite catalyst exhibits outstanding ORR activity with an onset potential of 1.01 V, which is on par with commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst. The catalyst also displayed a remarkable half-wave potential of 0.9 V and a limiting current density of 4.7 mA/cm2, both of which were higher than that of Pt/C. Such Pt-free composite catalysts offer a promising solution to sustainable fuel cell applications.
